Award.AwardTitle: RI: Medium: Quantifying Causality in Distributed Spatial Temporal Brain Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A key hurdle in studies of brain function is to be able to measure not only what signals are correlated with one another, but also how they are causally related. Correlation quantifies linear dependence, while causality is capable of distinguishing which brain area is leading the correlated counterparts; causality puts an arrow into correlation. Causality is a difficult problem in data analysis and here a novel measure of conditional statistical dependence to evaluate causality is proposed. The ultimate practical goal is to elucidate the principles of cognitive processing and provide online cognitive feedback to human subjects performing complex tasks.

The objective of this project is to use a recently developed paradigm for electroencephalogram (EEG) quantification based on periodic visual stimulation to improve the signal to noise ratio of visual stimulation on a pre-determined EEG frequency band (here around 10 Hz). The goal is to develop advanced signal processing techniques based on instantaneous frequency (Hilbert transform) to quantify the instantaneous amplitude of a visual stimulus in 32 channels over the scalp.

A recently developed measure of local statistical dependence in the joint space called correntropy will be utilized to evaluate the dependency among instantaneous amplitude time series collected over the scalp. The maximum value of correntropy is a measure of statistical dependence, which is the first step towards causality. To achieve a causality measure, conditional dependence will be evaluated by extending correntropy to conditional correntropy, first for triplets of variables and them to subspaces of arbitrary dimensions. Correntropy is a nonparametric measure of dependence; hence, the new method will be compared to linear and nonlinear Granger causality methods implemented in reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces.

These algorithms will be tested on data collected from human subjects in a study of affective visual perception. The goal is to study and quantify the re-entry hypothesis of emotional perception -- that re-entrant modulation originating from higher-order cortices is responsible for enhanced activation in the occipital cortex when emotionally arousing stimuli are perceived. The signal processing and statistical methods developed here will provide a way to identify dependent EEG channels and causal relationships amongst them during the presentation of the stimulus, effectively tracing the flow of neural activity from the stimulated visual areas to frontal areas and back to the visual cortex.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project outcomes have three facets: scientific discoveries, applications to brain science and education of the workforce.

 

Scientific Discoveries

Quantifying similarity in data (signals or images) using a data processing approach is a difficult problem because the available statistical tools are neither sensitive nor specific enough to address arbitrary forms of similarity. Moreover, most have free parameters that are difficult to set and change results. The ones that are parameter free are not very powerful (correlation), but they are the ones most often used because they are practical. There is therefore the need to propose and validate new measures of similarity for data that are powerful and easy to use. This proposal developed a measure of similarity, more specifically statistical dependence ,called generalized measure of association (GMA), with no free parameter, which competes with the best in the field. The application domains range from engineering, data science to medicine and therefore the potential impact of this research is high.

 

Application to cognitive neuroscience

The area that we have explored to validate GMA was the analysis of large-scale brain networks. When one brain area “talks” momentarily to another, the electrical signals collected from the corresponding brain areas become more similar because there is an exchange of information. GMA can be used to quantify these minute changes in similarity and elucidate which, and when, brain areas communicate during human behavior experiments. This helps researchers and clinicians understand better how the human brain works, and potentially deliver new ways to diagnose brain disease. Another important feature of the electroencephalogram (brain waves) is that the instrumentation to collect the signal is non-invasive, low cost, and becoming more and more ambulatory. 

 

As an example from one of our papers (Figure 1 top row) we show the evolution of GMA over time estimated from the EEG over an area that mediates attention (the parietal cortex), which is encircled on the left. Red means high values of GMA and blue low values. We plot the evolution over time (114 msec resolution) of the GMA versus two other measures of dependence (correlation and mutual information). GMA is more stable and increasing in value, which shows that the brain is progressively recognizing the face. In the bottom row we show how the GMA over the full head evolves over time, and conclude that communication across different brain areas for a meaningful stimulus such as a face heightens communication between brain areas doing different things.

 

Education of the work force

We have written nine journal publications as well as eight conference proceedings with our discoveries and validation studies to disseminate the theory and the algorithms to the scientific community. Moreover three Ph.D. students graduated with funds from this grant and we also trained a postdoctoral fellow. They are all working in the industry and academia.
